messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Dem Bones...
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, When I think of masame hada in tsuba, it s a like a puff pastry crust in the rim and the sukashi.  In your ko_shoami image I think it s a weld between
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
When I think of masame hada in tsuba, it's a like a puff pastry crust in the rim and the sukashi. In your ko_shoami image I think it's a weld between layers and something like masame hada. I wouldn't consider that tekkotsu.

The owari_mimi doesn't look like masame hada to me. But most all tsuba forging would result in some sort of masame in the rim.

Jim


3. There are running bones and there is masame hada. The ones that really look like masame hada are just the layers in the iron.

Hi Jim, ok, so this is Masame hada ?

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/owari-mimi.jpg

and this is a running bone or a fold ?, it goes around 3 sides of the tsuba, mostly unbroken.

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/ko_shoami_bones.jpg

cheers

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Dem Bones...
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, Agreed, Sharaku prices are positively Tokubetsu Juyo. 1. One or two tekkotsu are usually more interesting than none.  Most good pieces of the types that
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
Agreed, Sharaku prices are positively Tokubetsu Juyo.

1. One or two tekkotsu are usually more interesting than none. Most good pieces of the types that have tekkotsu will have them distributed here and there around the rim. Some pieces are positively bristling with them, and while it's a matter of taste it can get to be a bit much. While one or two small bones may not have much carry much "aesthetic weight" they are a pretty good clue that the iron is not just homogenous factory plate.

2. Yes, they're mostly visible on the rim only, although Kanayama, Yamakichi, Hoan, etc., will show them on the face as well. I think that it may be a function more of how the plate is finished than the forging. If you file/grind/sand the surface down, the bones aren't going to be visible unless some later process (rust, wear, ?) brings them out. I think that where to "put" or "leave" bones was an aesthetic choice.

3. There are running bones and there is masame hada. The ones that really look like masame hada are just the layers in the iron. I think typically if they stand out the guard was finished with some sort of etching process, or the layers were brought out by rusting. A running bone is not as obvious or as uniform as masame hada. It's a true tekkotsu that will be visible for a centimeter or few around the rim. It is also probably following a higher carbon layer, but it's not as obvious as a masame hada. It's frequently seen in early Akasaka.

4. Without seeing the piece I don't know. I've never seen inlay used to fill in voids in the forging, though. On the other hand, if some of the gold fell out, you will still see the slots cut for the inlay. Nunome should be a definite but shallow cross hatch (cloth) pattern. Of course hira-zogan or other techniques would be small cuts.

Short form answers, but I hope that gets at your questions.

Jim

>
yes, of course. That was meant as a " comment " on prices achieved so
the juyo level tsuba does not appear " ridiculous " .

Questions on tsuba......
1. what's the ball park figure on amount of bones that usually appear
in iron tsuba ? Is one or two still consider " good " ( better than
none )? I have a few that show no more than two while others are
allover the place ( mimi, that is ).
2. I notice most bones appear on the mimi but not( usually ) the flat
surface, is it due to the forging process ? ( may be because I don't
have the fortune to own a Yamakichibai , EARLY Hoan? =( )
3.I have notice a few tsuba that show running bones, almost like masame
hada , are they bones or just folding process that show the layers ?
4. The ko-Shoami tsuba I have in the folder also show traces of "
hada ", I notice one on the mimi that is a circle (like mokume ) which
is not bone, may be the gold nunome on the flat surfce of the rim is to
fill in those " openining edges " of mokume hada as I see nodefinite
pattern to the nunome ?

Muchias Gracias.......

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Dem Bones...
messages.msgSnippet: A couple of quick things to think about... Note that some of the first tsuba makers to sign their names made work with just these irregularities, and their
messages.messageBody:
A couple of quick things to think about...

Note that some of the first tsuba makers to sign their names made work with just these irregularities, and their work was highly valued. Nobuie, Hoan, Yamakichibei.

Also note the tea wares that were in fashion at the time and very highly valued as well. Raku, Shino, Oribe. Worth looking up if you're not familiar with ceramics.

It is true in tea ware at the time that earlier, purely utilitarian, non-art pieces were sometimes elevated to high regard and staggering monetary value.

Jim



Something which has bothered me for some time now is the lack of
historic record keeping of the early tsubako (pre Edo). With the
exception of the Goto there doesn't seem to be too much of a record.
Now there was a record of the sword smiths. This is why I question
the 'relative' value of the tsubako before Edo. After the civil war
period artistic merit became more important and all of a sudden we
see records of the tsubako. It may be possible that we are
dogmatizing the whole iron tsuba field, in other words making it more
important than it was ever viewed by the people of those times. Now
it is also important to remember that there is nothing wrong with
recognizing artistic beauty where it was not appreciated before. I
just have to wonder if sometimes we are overdoing it, that's all.
The 'beautiful' tekotsu bumplies on the mimi were just not worth the
time or effort to smooth off, and the 'surface texturing' was done to
hide the irregularities in the metal.




[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

> bit of idolitry

> tekotsu we see in
> the early guards is from their being made from
> scraps of steel left
> over from swordmaking or other purposes and the
> admixture of different
> pieces led to the inclussions of differing densities
> and furthermore
> that the relative unimportance of the guard to the
> sword made the bumps
> around the ede a moot issue? It seems that later on
> when the
> craftsmanship went up the tekotsu went away. Oh
> boy, I'm going to get
> it from this one!
>
>
>
>

historic record keeping of the early tsubako (pre Edo). With the

Now there was a record of the sword smiths. This is why I question
the 'relative' value of the tsubako before Edo. After the civil war

that type of iron in mid/late Edo days ( till the revival days of
shinshinto ).

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Dem Bones...
messages.msgSnippet: I think I can answer some of this.  Just like in swords, making your own steel stopped.  You may have heard of factory plate .  Basically, you could buy the
messages.messageBody:
I think I can answer some of this. Just like in
swords, making your own steel stopped. You may have
heard of "factory plate". Basically, you could buy
the steel to make the tsuba, and many schools/artists
got away from the plate and focused more on the
decoration. From my reading, the truly outstanding
smiths were able to do both: have a great plate while
having a superb design. As a student of tsuba you
need to concentrate on the plate and not get
sidetracked by fancy stuff (poorly paraphrazing some
sensei)
Ken

messages.subject: Dem Bones...
messages.msgSnippet: OK -- now this is heresy, blasphemy, and possibly a bit of idolitry throwm in for good measure.  Is it possible that the tekotsu we see in the early guards is
messages.messageBody:
OK -- now this is heresy, blasphemy, and possibly a bit of idolitry
throwm in for good measure. Is it possible that the tekotsu we see in
the early guards is from their being made from scraps of steel left
over from swordmaking or other purposes and the admixture of different
pieces led to the inclussions of differing densities and furthermore
that the relative unimportance of the guard to the sword made the bumps
around the ede a moot issue? It seems that later on when the
craftsmanship went up the tekotsu went away. Oh boy, I'm going to get
it from this one!
